translation: Ben must be swimming right now.
Ben is swimming/swims.

comment:
a) If X happens, Ben will swim.
b) Ben habitually swims.

translation: Ben is under the obligation to swim.

words: Ben’in bu saat-te yüz-üyor ol-ma-sı lazım.
gloss: Ben-gen this time-loc swim.ipfv be-inf-3s.poss lazım.cop.3s
translation: Ben is supposed to be swimming right now.

words: Ben’in bu saat-te yüz-üyor ol-ma-sı gerek.
gloss: Ben-gen this time-loc swim.ipfv be-inf-3s.poss gerek
translation: Ben is supposed to be swimming right now.
Ben must be at school.
comment: preferred

translation: Ben is likely at school.
Ben will be at school.
comment: (more formal/literary/…)

translation: It MUST be in C.
It MUST be in C.
comment: preferred. Intuition: “-DIR” somehow weakens the statement and this clashes with the certainty that the ball is in C.

translation: The ball has to be in C.
comment: The consult’s comment: I tend to accept ‘şart’ in an epistemic necessity context. I feel like its deontic use might be more common? Another speaker tells me that he doesn’t like it as an epistemic.

translation: The ball has to be in C.
The ball has to be in C.
comment: Perhaps a slight dispreference for ‘gerek.’

translation: It must be that the dog is not in the house.
The dog is probably not in the house.
comment: DIR is weaker than MA. And therefore it is dispreferred

translation: Ann must probably be at the lake right now.
Ann might be at the lake right now.
Ann must be at the lake right now.
comment: slightly dispreferred to olmalıdır

translation: Ann is probably at the lake right now.
It must be raining right now.
comment: slightly preferred

translation: it is raining right now.
It must be raining right now.
It must be raining right now.

words: #Şu an-da Goa’da yağmur yağ-ıyor ol-ma=sı şart.
gloss: DEM moment Goa.loc rain precipitate be.nmz.3s ŞART.cop.3s
translation: It’s necessarily raining in Goa right now.
comment: ‘şart’ feels too strong here.

translation: Mary SHOULD be at home

comment: Just “-mali” feels too strong in this context.

translation: Mary SHOULD be at home
He might not come.
comment: the morpheme “ABIL” (citation form: -(y)AbIl) can also be used to express abilitative modality

translation: He might not come.
Grace’s necklace might have gotten lost.

words: Kedi içeride ol-abil-ir, (ya da) dışarıda ol-abil-ir.
gloss: Cat inside be-MOD-aor or outside be-MOD-aor.
translation: The cat MAY be inside or the cat MAY be outside.

words: Kedi içeride de ol-abil-ir dışarıda da ol-abili-r.
gloss: Cat inside conj be-abil-aor outside conj be-abil-aor
translation: The cat MAY be inside or the cat MAY be outside.
comment: (da…da is conjunction )

translation: Daniel MAY go to New York.

words: Daniel’in New York’a gid-iyor ol-ma-sı mümkün.
gloss: Daniel-gen new york-dat go-ipfv be-NMZ-poss.3s possible.COP.PRES
translation: It’s possible that Daniel is going to New York.
Daniel MAY go to New York.
It’s not the case that she must be at home.
comment: The reason "gerek" might be odd here is because it's not a copular predicate, but "degil" is copular negation.

translation: It’s not the case that she must be at home.
comment: Negation on top of modality (gerek, lazim) seems to disfavor the epistemic reading. (The deontic reading comes to mind for the above example.)

translation: No. We’re not necessarily there.

words: #Mary evde olmalı ama evde olması gerek değil
translation: Mary must be at home but it’s not necessarily the case that she must be at home.
comment: Contradiction.

words: #Mary’nin evde olması gerek ama evde olmamalı.
translation: Mary must be at home but it’s not the case that she must be at home…
comment: This is pretty weird when both modals are read as epistemic. I’m pushed to repair the contradiction by reading at least one of them as deontic. (This should suffice to suggest that “gerek” is necessity, while avoiding the negation problem.)

words: Mary evde olmalı ama evde olması şart değil
gloss: Mary home.loc be.MA.aor but home.loc be.ma.3s.poss condition neg.cop.3.pres
translation: Mary should be at home, but I leave open the possibility that she is not
comment: Not contradictory/less contradictory than above. (the second part with şart seems to weaken the force of MA in the first conjunct)

words: Mary evde olabilir ama evde olması şart değil.
gloss: Mary home.loc be.abil.aor but home.loc be.ma.3s.poss condition neg.cop.3.pres
translation: Mary could be at home but it’s not necessarily the case that she’s at home.
Ben can’t be at home.
comment: Ben CAN’T be at home.
column7: This is the negation of “ol-abil-ir” be-ABIL-aor. The modal suffix ABIL is contained in ola.ma-z. Ol-ma-z is “be-neg-aor” without the modal. So the “a” in “olamaz” is coming from the modal suffix (Note also that the shape of agreement is also conditioned by negation… gel-ir “come-aor.3s” but gel-me-z, “come-neg-aor.3s”.)

translation: The ball can’t be in C.
The ball can’t be in C.
You MUST wear a helmet.
I MUST wear a helmet.
I MUST wear a helmet.
Visitors must leave before 6.
comment: [maybe preference for ‘lazim’]

translation: Visitors must leave before 6.
Visitors must leave before 6.
comment: seems slightly unnatural in the context; but can imagine someone uttering this in 13; can be an announcement over the PA when it is close to 6pm

translation: Maybe I should dress up.
It might be good if I dressed up.
I have to dress up.
comment: (perhaps natural in 16 but feels like the speaker is imposing a requirement that is stronger than what the host required to themself)

translation: People who don’t work here should wash their hands too.
comment: [imposing requirement that may be stronger than what the actual requirement is]

words: Burada çalış-ma-yan-lar da ellerini yıka-sa-lar iyi ol-ur.
gloss: Here work-neg-rel-pl too their.hands wash-cond-3pl good be-aor
translation: It would be good if people who don’t work here also washed their hands.
comment: [weaker than the first]

translation: It would be good if I wore a mask.
I have to wear a mask.
Martin may go on the ferris wheel.

comment: Can’t be used to report on what’s allowed, I don’t think. Let’s assume that he’s allowed to go on the ferris wheel, but he’s unable to for some other reason, maybe his legs are injured or something. Then, the sentence is false.

translation: You can enter.
I don’t have to dress up.
I don’t have to dress up.
comment: gerek is dispreferred under the değil negation.

translation: I don’t have to dress up.
One does not ride a motorcycle without a helmet.
You’re not allowed to ride a motorcycle without a helmet.

comment: It is not possible (circumstantially?) for you to ride a motorcycle without a helmet. <- Sentence false under this interpretation.

words: A’dan B’ye git-mek ist[e]-iyor-sa-n…Bu yol-u kullan-ma-n gerek.
gloss: A-abl B-dat go-inf want-pres-cond-2s This road-acc use-nmz-2s gerek
translation: If you want to go from A to B, You have to take this road.

words: A’dan B’ye git-mek ist[e]-iyor-sa-n…Bu yol-u kullan-ma-n lazım.
gloss: A-abl B-dat go-inf want-pres-cond-2s This road-acc use-nmz-2s lazim
translation: If you want to go from A to B, You have to take this road.
You should take this road. / I recommend that you take this road.
comment: [feels like a suggestion] too weak for the context

translation: you should take the bus.
you should take the bus.

comment: This is too strong.
This is too strong.

translation: you should take the bus.
comment: Here: it could be that the force of lazim is hedged by bence. However, the contrast between “gerek” and “lazim” isn’t that crisp. They can both be hedged by “bence.”

translation: You can take road 1.

comment: No teleological possibility reading.

words: Otobüse binmelisin diye bir şey yok.
gloss: Bus-dat ride-MOD-2s C one thing neg.exist
translation: Lit. “There’s no such thing as ‘you have to ride the bus."

words: Otobüse binebilirim diye bir şey yok.
gloss: Bus-dat ride-MOD-aor-1s C one thing neg.exist
translation: I don’t allow you to ride the bus.
comment: “There’s no such thing as ‘I’m allowed to ride the bus.’”

words: A’dan B’ye gidiyorsan…Başka bir yoldan gidemezsin.
gloss: A-from B-dat go-pres-cond  Other one road-abl go-ABIL.neg.aor-2s
translation: If you’re going from A to B, You can’t take another road.
I HAVE to pee so badly!
I HAVE to pee so badly!

comment: feels too weak in the context

translation: Oh… I have to pee.
comment: External perspective on self.

words: Suyun zaten sağ taraf-tan çıkması lazım
gloss: Water.gen already right side.abl exit-nmz-3s lazim
translation: the water must come out from the right output.

words: Suyun zaten sağ taraf-tan çıkması gerek
gloss: Water.gen already right side.abl exit-nmz-3s gerek
translation: the water must come out from the right output.
Duku trees can grow here.
Duku trees could be growing here.

comment: For some reason, mümkün is not possible in the Italian food context, but acceptable in the ‘lift the piano’ context.

translation: Amy can lift the piano.
comment: For some reason, mümkün is not possible in the Italian food context, but acceptable in the ‘lift the piano’ context.

translation: Amy can make traditional Italian foods.

gloss: Amy traditional Italian foods.acc make.ipfv be..abil.pres
translation: Amy could be making traditional Italian foods.

words: Bu volkan beş sene içinde patlayabilir.
gloss: This volcano five years within explode-MOD-aor.3s
translation: This volcano could explode within five years.

words: Bu volkanın beş sene içinde patlaması mümkün
gloss: This volcano-gen five years within explode-inf-3s.poss possible.cop.3s
translation: It’s possible that this volcano might explode within five years.
I can’t keep myself from sneezing.
comment: (cf. the positive ‘tut-abil-iyor-um’) implies that the subject is trying to not sneeze

translation: It’s not possible for me not to sneeze.
comment: It’s more like an objective impossibility to not sneeze.

translation: The water can’t come out of the left anyway.
It’s not possible for the water to come out of the left.
I need to buy this.
I need to buy this.
I need to buy this.
I want to go to the movies.
My friend wants to come to see me.
